author: Fernando Teixeira
title: Sertã: Nadadores trazem nove medalhas de Torneio de Velocidade
text:
Sertã: Nadadores trazem nove medalhas de Torneio de Velocidade 16 de Janeiro de 2025 Visualizações: 9 A equipa de natação do CCD (Centro de Cultura e Desporto do Pessoal da Câmara Municipal) Sertã marcou presença no Torneio Inter-Regional de Velocidade, que se realizou em Tomar no passado domingo, dia 12 de janeiro. A equipa sertaginense participou com 25 nadadores e trouxe para casa nove medalhas.
Organizado pela Associação de Natação do Distrito de Santarém (ANDS) em colaboração com a Associação de Natação do Interior Centro (ANIC), este Torneio Inter-Regional da Velocidade contou com a participação de 18 equipas das associações de Santarém e do Interior Centro, envolvendo cerca de 250 nadadores.
Os atletas sertaginenses, entre os escalões de infantis, juvenis e absoluto (juniores e seniores), fizeram neste torneio 20 finais e conquistaram um total de nove medalhas, resultados que colocaram a Sertã no quinto lugar do ranking de medalhas.
Os infantis estiveram em especial destaque: Afonso Alves conquistou o 1º lugar nos 50 costas, 2º nos 50 mariposa e o 3º nos 100 estilos. Leonor Tavares venceu nos 50 bruços e Margarida Antunes ficou em 3º nos 50 mariposa. Nos estafetas infantis, a equipa feminina (Benedita Ribeiro, Leonor Tavares, Margarida Antunes e Leonor Silva) conquistou o primeiro lugar, e a equipa masculina (Rui Douvens, Afonso Alves, Sérgio Alves e Martin Nunes) classificaram-se em segundo. Já em juvenis, a atleta Inês farinha classificou-se em 3º lugar nos 50 costas e nos 100 estilos. Pode consultar aqui todos os resultados deste Torneio de Velocidade.
Para além dos nadadores mencionados, a equipa de natação do CCD Sertã (acompanhada pelos treinadores Hugo Carvalho e Davide Martins) fez-se representar por Afonso Filipe, Bernardo Pires, Clara Marçal, Daniela Ribeiro, Duarte Matos, Helena Marçal, Joana Matias, João Barreto, Madalena Rolo, Matilde Cardoso, Matilde Lourenço, Matilde Simões, Rafael Ferreira, Simão Antunes, Tomás Lourenço e Tomás Gaspar. Recorde-se que muitos destes atletas foram convocados para integrar a seleção regional da ANIC , que prestará provas já este fim de semana, na Taça Vale do Tejo (em Abrantes).

title: Collaborative Home Care Maintains Its Tradition of Exceptional Home Care in Greenwich, CT | User | theeveningleader.com
text:
Collaborative Home Care in Greenwich, CT, continues its tradition of exceptional senior care, emphasizing accessibility, personalized service, and compassion. Led by Bryan Knust, the organization is dedicated to exceeding client expectations and ensuring families have access to premier care. For more details, Google it at https://collaborativehomecare.com. Greenwich, CT - Collaborative Home Care, a beacon of excellence in the home care sector, is proud to announce its ongoing commitment to the Greenwich community. Renowned for providing unparalleled senior care services, Collaborative Home Care emphasizes the importance of accessibility, compassion, and personalized care in meeting the needs of seniors. This announcement underscores the vital role of quality home care services in families seeking the best care for their loved ones.
Bryan Knust, the visionary behind Collaborative Home Care, highlights the core values that drive the organization's success. “At Collaborative Home Care, our goal is not just to meet the basic needs of our clients but to exceed expectations by delivering comprehensive, personalized care tailored to each individual's requirements. Our dedication to the Greenwich community is unwavering, and we are committed to ensuring families have access to the premier senior care they deserve,” stated Knust.
In an era of ever-increasing demand for reliable senior care, Collaborative Home Care continues to set the standard for excellence. The organization's wide range of services, from personal care and companionship to home health care, reflects a deep understanding of seniors' multifaceted needs, ensuring that every client receives the highest care and attention.
As Collaborative Home Care forges ahead, its unwavering dedication to improving the lives of seniors in Greenwich, CT, remains clear. The organization's efforts to maintain the highest quality of care have solidified its position as a community cornerstone, offering peace of mind to families seeking the best for their elderly loved ones.
For more information about Collaborative Home Care and their home care in Greenwich, CT , please visit their website at https://collaborativehomecare.com
About Collaborative Home Care:
Collaborative Home Care is a leading provider of senior care services in Greenwich, CT. Focused on delivering personalized, compassionate care, the organization prides itself on its commitment to excellence and its ability to meet the diverse needs of the senior community. Collaborative Home Care is more than a service provider; it is a trusted partner in ensuring every client's well-being and dignity.

author: NPT Staff
title: Washington State Man Sentenced To Jail For Approaching Steamboat Geyser In Yellowstone
text: A Washington state man who left a boardwalk to approach Steamboat Geyser in Yellowstone National Park has been sentenced to seven days in jail and fined $1,500. According to a Justice Department release, Viktor Pyshniuk, 21 of Lynwood, Washington, also was placed on two years of unsupervised release and received a two-year ban from entering Yellowstone. He also was ordered to pay a $30 mandatory court processing fee and $20 special assessment. According to court documents, a Yellowstone law enforcement officer was dispatched to the thermal area at Steamboat Geyser on April 19, 2024, after an on-duty park employee reported a person walking off the boardwalk at that location. The employee had taken a photo of the defendant who had clearly crossed over the fence and was walking up the hillside within 15-20 feet of Steamboat Geyser’s steam vent. When contacted, Pyshniuk told the officer he left the boardwalk to take photos. While speaking with Pyshniuk, the officer showed him the signs posted throughout the area stating it is illegal to leave the boardwalk and explained that walking in a thermal area is very dangerous due to possible weak ground layer, the geothermal features of mud pots, heated steam and water, and all other dangers associated with walking in a heated, unpredictable geothermal area. Magistrate Judge Stephanie A. Hambrick imposed the sentence on June 4. During sentencing she explained to the defendant that the sentence was designed to deter him, specifically, but also the public from leaving the boardwalk in this area. She expressed her concern that the defendant’s actions were seen by the people around him, and they might have thought it was okay to do the same thing. “Trespassing in closed, thermal areas of Yellowstone National Park is dangerous and harms the natural resource,” said Acting United States Attorney Eric Heimann. “In cases like this one where we have strong evidence showing a person has willfully disregarded signs and entered a closed, thermal area, federal prosecutors will seek significant penalties, including jail time.” Steamboat Geyser is a prominent feature in the park and the world’s tallest active geyser, but it is also the most dangerous. It has erratic and unpredictable eruptions that can rise anywhere from six feet to 300 feet high. In the last four years, the intervals between eruptions ranged anywhere from three to 89 days according to the Yellowstone website . Judge Hambrick also explained that the three-foot fencing around the boardwalk is a clear sign that the area is closed and prohibited from entering.
